message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ovulation occurs when a fully matured egg is released by the ovary, and progesterone levels rise after ovulation. Estrogen is involved in the follicular phase, while gonadotropin-releasing hormone and luteinizing hormone play a role in stimulating ovulation. However, progesterone is the most reliable indicator that ovulation has occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Estrogen and Gonadotropin-releasing hormone both increase before ovulation, but the best indicator of ovulation is an increase in progesterone levels. This increase stimulates the thickening of the endometrium in preparation for implantation. Luteinizing hormone also increases before ovulation and triggers the release of a mature egg. However, it is the increase in progesterone levels that confirms that ovulation has occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Progesterone levels increase after ovulation, indicating the release of the egg from the ovary. Estrogen and gonadotropin-releasing hormone levels increase prior to ovulation to stimulate follicle growth, while luteinizing hormone levels peak just prior to ovulation to trigger ovulation. However, progesterone levels remain elevated after ovulation has occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ovulation occurs when a mature egg is released from the ovary, which results in an increase in progesterone levels. Luteinizing hormone also plays a role in ovulation, but a rise in progesterone levels is a more reliable indicator of ovulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While LH surge does indicate impending ovulation, the best indicator that ovulation has occurred is the increase in progesterone levels, which occurs after ovulation. Estrogen and GnRH levels also increase but are not specific to ovulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. After ovulation, the corpus luteum produces progesterone, which helps prepare the uterus for possible implantation of a fertilized egg. Therefore, an increase in progesterone is the best indicator that ovulation has occurred. Estrogen levels rise before ovulation, but they do not directly indicate ovulation. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone and luteinizing hormone are involved in regulating ovulation but do not increase after ovulation has occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The best indicator that ovulation has occurred is an increase in progesterone levels. Luteinizing hormone is responsible for triggering ovulation, but its increase alone is not sufficient to confirm ovulation. Estrogen and gonadotropin-releasing hormone play important roles in the menstrual cycle but are not the best indicators of ovulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. After ovulation, the corpus luteum produces progesterone, which prepares the uterus for potential implantation. Therefore, an increase in progesterone is the best indicator that ovulation has occurred. Estrogen and luteinizing hormone levels also increase during the menstrual cycle, but they do not necessarily indicate ovulation. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone is not directly involved in ovulation but rather acts as a regulator of the menstrual cycle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While luteinizing hormone (LH) surge does cause ovulation, it occurs before ovulation. Progesterone levels surge after ovulation and are a better indicator that ovulation has occurred. Estrogen levels increase prior to ovulation and gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) regulates the release of LH and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), but their levels do not necessarily indicate ovulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. After ovulation, the corpus luteum produces progesterone to prepare the endometrium for implantation. Therefore, an increase in progesterone levels is the best indicator that ovulation has occurred. Estrogen levels rise before ovulation, but they do not guarantee ovulation. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone and luteinizing hormone levels increase during ovulation, but they are not the best indicators.
